issues.title: Relation to HTTP Alt-Svc headers and certificate subjects
issues.author: Saklad5
issues.body:
https://github.com/bemasc/svcb-dane/blob/6e945bef3591b06355327f17117aec4169db1cc6/draft-rebs-dnsop-svcb-dane.md?plain=1#L67

If I understand this draft correctly, that means that the client following a PKIX-EE record does **not** ask for a certificate with the name of the origin, but instead asks for a certificate with the name of the endpoint.

Does this mean that a DANE-compatible client will require distinct certificates depending on whether they use Alt-Svc or HTTPS records to locate the endpoint?

---

Consider the following (DNSSEC-validated) records:

```DNS
endpoint.example.               86400	IN	AAAA	2001:db8::
_443._tcp.endpoint.example.	86400	IN	TLSA	1 1 1 [endpoint keys]
origin.example.                 86400	IN	AAAA	2001:db8::1
origin.example.		        86400	IN	HTTPS	1 endpoint.example.
_443._tcp.origin.example.	86400	IN	TLSA	1 1 1 [origin keys]
```

A client that does not support HTTPS records might connect to `origin.example` directly, using an SNI of `origin.example` and comparing it to the TLSA record at `_443._tcp.origin.example`. The response could include the header `Alt-Svc: http/1.1="endpoint.example.com:443"`.

A subsequent request might be directed at `endpoint.example`, with the same SNI and TLSA record (based on [RFC 7838](https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc7838)). Thus, no certificate for `endpoint.example` is requested or needed.

In contrast, a client that supports HTTPS records would connect to `endpoint.example`, using an SNI of `endpoint.example` and comparing it to the TLSA record at `_443._tcp.endpoint.example`. This means that a certificate for `endpoint.example` *is* required, and a certificate for `origin.example` is never used.

---

Is this the intended behavior? It strikes me as rather confusing, if so: an example explicitly demonstrating this would be welcome. Alt-Svc headers and HTTPS records are equivalent in most respects, so such a divergence is worth noting.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
> Does this mean that a DANE-compatible client will require distinct certificates depending on whether they use Alt-Svc or HTTPS records to locate the endpoint?

DANE for HTTP is not implemented anywhere, to my knowledge, and [might even be insecure](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-barnes-dane-uks-00).  I don't think anyone has figured out how DANE would work with Alt-Svc.  This draft doesn't change that.  Also, Alt-Svc is [falling out of favor](https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/ietf-http-wg/2022OctDec/0062.html) and may be headed for deprecation.

I don't think this draft should try to address HTTP Alt-Svc.  I suspect the right answer is that DANE and Alt-Svc are not compatible ... but this is a moot point, because nobody uses DANE with HTTP, and Alt-Svc seems to be on its way out.

comments.author: Saklad5
comments.body:
> DANE for HTTP is not implemented anywhere, to my knowledge, and [might even be insecure](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-barnes-dane-uks-00).

I'd like to see DANE for HTTP accrue support eventually. Certificate Transparency is a good solution, but it isn't suitable for everything. DANE also has the advantage of being relatively easy for resource-constrained clients to implement.

I use PKIX-EE records by default, at least for certificates that would pass it anyway. They avoid the issue described in that expired Internet Draft, such as it is. I'm not convinced that actually constitutes an attack, so much as a reverse proxy.

issues.title: DNSDIR Review Notes
issues.author: bemasc
issues.body:
Credit: Patrick Mevzek

*

It updates 6698, but it also focuses mostly on operational issues/guidance,
which is what 7671 is about, so maybe it should also be marked as updating 7671
in addition of 6698?

*

Section 1.

— Nit: `_8080._tcp.example.com.` does not appear in specific “code” font in
HTML output of draft, while other names later in document do, so I guess just a
formatting change.

— Potentially use “TLSA records” (plural) in various places instead of “the
TLSA record” as this gives the impression there can be only one.

— Introduction says the document does two things: giving details using DANE
with SVCB and also how to use DANE with QUIC. However, neither the document
title nor the abstract of it mention QUIC, only SVCB is mentioned. If the
document does both, perhaps both points should be clearly listed early on
(title + abstract), or otherwise (as SVCB and QUIC are fairly distinct things
in my view), it should be split in two documents, each one focusing on one
point only.

*

Section 3

— name of section: I would suggest using SVCB specifically instead of Service
Bindings Same for title and abstract of document in fact.

— s/This draft applies/This document applies/ (or specification, or other
terms, but not “draft”) Maybe other occurrences of “draft” later on should be
replaced as well.

— “if SVCB resolution was entirely secure” : maybe mentioning it once that
secure here means with DNSSEC along all the paths (DNS answers) taken? Or
pointing to somewhere where secure is defined (maybe: §4.1 of RFC6698?)

— “In usage modes other than DANE-EE(3)”: shouldn't that also include DANE-TA
case at same level than DANE-EE?

— section 3
“Section 6 of [RFC7671] says:” (present)
vs section 4
“Section 3 of [RFC6698] defined the protocol prefix used for constructing TLSA
QNAMEs, and said:” (past)

I suggest using either present or past tense in both cases, as the intent is
the same (redefining something coming from elsewhere)

*

Section 4

— name of section: I would make sure to list QUIC explicitly, otherwise seems
too generic

— “this draft Updates the above sentence as follows:”

Replace “draft” by document or equivalent and lowercase “Updates”.

— “udp” (DTLS [I-D.draft-ietf-tls-dtls13])
Shouldn't that instead reference by RFC9147 “The Datagram Transport Layer
Security (DTLS) Protocol Version 1.3”?

*

Section 5.1

— Please replace examples of `alias.net`, `provider.com` with things under
`.example` TLD.

— “TLSA  <provider keys>” Why plural? Possibly just ellipse the whole <> part,
as it could be a hash too, etc.

— “Service consumers are expected to use CNAME or SVCB AliasMode”, yet the
example given is using only HTTPS record and not SVCB record. Maybe use
multiple examples?

— Perhaps add that this works mostly for DANE-EE and DANE-TA use cases?

*

Section 6

— “might use DANE for some conection” => connection

— While not having actual element to provide, I feel the section to be a little
too simple and specially the last paragraph, saying basically “insecurely
resolved is not safe”, without giving guidance or at least detailing the
tradeoffs between various possible scenarios (ignoring unsecure results,
continue, etc.)

*

Section 7

— make sure all examples use IETF reserved names for hostnames (ex:
`example-cdn.com` => `cdn-foobar42.example`)

— “7.3. QUIC and CNAME”, not sure what the record on `https://urldefense.com/v3/__http://www.example.com__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!758lq070UDFG11STHGAG_isoz527_V1hsvhefnUuCdQdJXFOI8N_cc-LKCrnJfhLu0iX3qBp6aA$ ` is
useful for? Or the URI should be `https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://www.example.com/*60?__;JQ!!Bt8RZUm9aw!758lq070UDFG11STHGAG_isoz527_V1hsvhefnUuCdQdJXFOI8N_cc-LKCrnJfhLu0iXjPBZQAo$

— “7.7. DNS ServiceMode”: perhaps use another TargetName to avoid having to say
“The TLSA base name is taken from the SVCB TargetName.”?

— “7.8. DNS AliasMode”: I don't understand the example given. Where does `ns1`
come from?

— nitpick/personal: I would prefer the examples to go from specific to general,
and as such I would put the two DNS cases currently at the end more in the
middle, right before “New scheme ServiceMode”

*

Section 8

— “IANA is instructed to add the following entry to the “Underscored and
Globally Scoped DNS Node Names” registry:” Give some references on where this
registry is located/where it is defined? (RFC 8553 maybe?)

issues.title: SECDIR Review Notes
issues.author: bemasc
issues.body:
Credit: Donald Eastlake

First page headings: "Updates" should just have the RFC number "6698" not "rfc6698" (See in the xml source where it says 'updates="rfc6698" '.)

Title: I suggest expanding a bit to something like the following, which the RFC Editor may want you to do anyway:
    "Using DNS Service Bindings (SVCB) with DNS-Based Authentication of Named Entities (DANE)"

Abstract: I think it should mention "_quic". I suggest something like

DNS Service Binding (SVCB) resource records (RRs) add a new form of name indirection to the DNS. This document specifies DNS-Based Authentication of Named Entities (DANE) interaction with Service Bindings to secure endpoints, including the use of ports and transports discovered via Service Parameters. It also specifies the _quic underscored DNS node name to designate the QUIC transport.

Section 1, last word of first paragraph: maybe "TLS" -> "TLS/DTLS".

This document would benefit from some additional terminology definitions in Section 2 for such things as SvcParam and SNI. Perhaps there should be a reference to the DNS terminology draft-ietf-dnsop-rfc8499bis-08.

Section 3, 2nd paragraph: "was entirely secure" -> "was entirely secured by DNSSEC".

Section 5.2: Is "Accidental" the right word in the Section name? Would "Erroneous" or some other word be better?
- It isn't clear from the text what a "third-party consumer" is. Maybe a figure with boxes would help. "third-party" is hyphenated in one place but not in another.
- In the last sentence, "take caution" sounds a little odd to me; suggest either "take care" or "be cautious".

Section 6, first line: suggest "property" -> "part"

Section 8: Seems more polite to say "requested" rather than "instructed".

issues.title: Unknown Key-Share attacks in a browser context
issues.author: bemasc
issues.body:
I think the UKS section might need a tweak to address the browser context: if the attacker can fool the browser into thinking that victim.example is attacker.example, it might be able to retrieve confidential resources and then access them from JS via the same-origin policy.

The conclusion is not really changed but the analysis is slightly different.

pulls.title: Clarify CNAME handling and add IANA section
pulls.author: bemasc

pulls.title: Minor revisions
pulls.body:
For normative text:
- Update abstract
- Clarify "final" means following AliasMode indirection
- Specify that TargetName CNAME target base domain must be resolved first
- Clarify that SNI and base name match the actual TLSA record found

For examples:
- State that DNSSEC is assumed for examples
- Add "URI" when describing example services for clarity
- Fix 0 priority in ServiceMode record
- Explain transport label is selected by client
- Explain CNAME fallback sequence
- Minor formatting

comments.body:
```suggestion
* The initial TLSA base domain MUST be the final SVCB TargetName used for this connection attempt.  (Names appearing earlier in a resolution chain are not used.)
```

```suggestion
If the SVCB TargetName contains a CNAME record, clients MUST first try to use the CNAME target as the TLSA base domain, with fallback to the final SVCB TargetName as the TLSA base domain, as described in {{Section 7 of RFC7671}}.
```

```suggestion
If the connection attempt is using HTTP/3, the transport label is set to `_quic`\; otherwise `_tcp` is used.
```

```suggestion
The initial TLSA QNAME would be one of:
```

```suggestion
The TLSA QNAME is `_8443._$PROTO.api.example.com`, where $PROTO is the appropriate value for the client-selected transport as discussed in {{protocols}} .
```
I liked this better the other way.  HTTPS does allow the chain to terminate with an AliasMode record.  This way seems too similar to the previous example.

pulls.author: Saklad5
pulls.body: I assume "Serving Binding" was not the intended term.
